natural problem: Find the smallest positive integer $a$ such that $x^4 + a^2$ is not prime for any integer $x.$
natural solution: For $1 \le a \le 7,$ we give a value of $x$ for which $x^4 + a^2$ is prime: \[ \begin{array}{c|c|c} a & x & a^4 + x^2 \\ \hline 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & 5 \\ 3 & 10 & 10009 \\ 4 & 1 & 17 \\ 5 & 2 & 41 \\ 6 & 1 & 37 \\

7 & 20 & 160049 \end{array} \]For $a = 8,$ \begin{align} x^4 + a^2 &= x^4 + 64 \\ &= x^4 + 16x^2 + 64 - 16x^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 8)^2 - (4x)^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 4x + 8)(x^2 - 4x + 8). \end{align}For any positive integer, both factors $x^2 + 4x + 8$ and $x^2 - 4x + 8$ are greater than 1, so $x^4 + 64$ is always composite.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a x :: int and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 + a powr 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. \<not> prime (P x)"
shows  "a = 8"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the smallest positive integer $a$ such that $x^4 + a^2$ is not prime for any integer $x.$ The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 For $1 \le a \le 7,$ we give a value of $x$ for which $x^4 + a^2$ is prime: \[ \begin{array}{c|c|c} a & x & a^4 + x^2 \\ \hline 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & 5 \\ 3 & 10 & 10009 \\ 4 & 1 & 17 \\ 5 & 2 & 41 \\ 6 & 1 & 37 \\
 7 & 20 & 160049 \end{array} \]For $a = 8,$ \begin{align} x^4 + a^2 &= x^4 + 64 \\ &= x^4 + 16x^2 + 64 - 16x^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 8)^2 - (4x)^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 4x + 8)(x^2 - 4x + 8). \end{align}For any positive integer, both factors $x^2 + 4x + 8$ and $x^2 - 4x + 8$ are greater than 1, so $x^4 + 64$ is always composite.
 Thus, the smallest such $a$ is $\boxed{8}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a x :: int and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 + a powr 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. \<not> prime (P x)"
shows  "a = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the value of $a$ such that $x^4 + a^2$ is never a prime number for any integer $x$. The final answer is $8$.

a_1.formal problem:

fixes a x :: int and prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. \<not> prime (x powr 4 + a powr 2)"
shows  "a = 8"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the smallest positive integer $a$ such that $x^4 + a^2$ is not prime for any integer $x.$ The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 For $1 \le a \le 7,$ we give a value of $x$ for which $x^4 + a^2$ is prime: \[ \begin{array}{c|c|c} a & x & a^4 + x^2 \\ \hline 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & 5 \\ 3 & 10 & 10009 \\ 4 & 1 & 17 \\ 5 & 2 & 41 \\ 6 & 1 & 37 \\

 Thus, the smallest such $a$ is $\boxed{8}.$

theorem
fixes a x :: int and prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. \<not> prime (x powr 4 + a powr 2)"

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x a :: int and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x a. P x = x powr 4 + a powr 2"
and h1 : "\<not>is_prime (P x)"
and h2 : "a > 0"
shows  "a = 8"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the smallest positive integer $a$ such that $x^4 + a^2$ is not prime for any integer $x.$ The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 For $1 \le a \le 7,$ we give a value of $x$ for which $x^4 + a^2$ is prime: \[ \begin{array}{c|c|c} a & x & a^4 + x^2 \\ \hline 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & 5 \\ 3 & 10 & 10009 \\ 4 & 1 & 17 \\ 5 & 2 & 41 \\ 6 & 1 & 37 \\
 7 & 20 & 160049 \end{array} \]For $a = 8,$ \begin{align} x^4 + a^2 &= x^4 + 64 \\ &= x^4 + 16x^2 + 64 - 16x^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 8)^2 - (4x)^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 4x + 8)(x^2 - 4x + 8). \end{align}For any positive integer, both factors $x^2 + 4x + 8$ and $x^2 - 4x + 8$ are greater than 1, so $x^4 + 64$ is always composite.
 Thus, the smallest such $a$ is $\boxed{8}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x a :: int and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x a. P x = x powr 4 + a powr 2"
and h1 : "\<not>is_prime (P x)"
and h2 : "a > 0"
shows  "a = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x a :: int and is_prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. \<exists>a. a > 0 \<and> not (is_prime (x powr 4 + a powr 2))"
shows  "\<exists>a. a = 8"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the smallest positive integer $a$ such that $x^4 + a^2$ is not prime for any integer $x.$ The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 For $1 \le a \le 7,$ we give a value of $x$ for which $x^4 + a^2$ is prime: \[ \begin{array}{c|c|c} a & x & a^4 + x^2 \\ \hline 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & 5 \\ 3 & 10 & 10009 \\ 4 & 1 & 17 \\ 5 & 2 & 41 \\ 6 & 1 & 37 \\
 7 & 20 & 160049 \end{array} \]For $a = 8,$ \begin{align} x^4 + a^2 &= x^4 + 64 \\ &= x^4 + 16x^2 + 64 - 16x^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 8)^2 - (4x)^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 4x + 8)(x^2 - 4x + 8). \end{align}For any positive integer, both factors $x^2 + 4x + 8$ and $x^2 - 4x + 8$ are greater than 1, so $x^4 + 64$ is always composite.
 Thus, the smallest such $a$ is $\boxed{8}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x a :: int and is_prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. \<exists>a. a > 0 \<and> not (is_prime (x powr 4 + a powr 2))"
shows  "\<exists>a. a = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: "For every integer $x$, there exists a positive integer $a$ such that $x^4 + a^2$ is not prime. Find a possible value for $a$. The answer is $8$."

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: nat and x :: int and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x a. P x a = (is_prime (x^4 + a^2))"
and h1 : "\<not>(\<exists>x. P x a)"
and h2 : "a > 0"
shows  "a = 8"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the smallest positive integer $a$ such that $x^4 + a^2$ is not prime for any integer $x.$ The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 For $1 \le a \le 7,$ we give a value of $x$ for which $x^4 + a^2$ is prime: \[ \begin{array}{c|c|c} a & x & a^4 + x^2 \\ \hline 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & 5 \\ 3 & 10 & 10009 \\ 4 & 1 & 17 \\ 5 & 2 & 41 \\ 6 & 1 & 37 \\
 7 & 20 & 160049 \end{array} \]For $a = 8,$ \begin{align} x^4 + a^2 &= x^4 + 64 \\ &= x^4 + 16x^2 + 64 - 16x^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 8)^2 - (4x)^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 4x + 8)(x^2 - 4x + 8). \end{align}For any positive integer, both factors $x^2 + 4x + 8$ and $x^2 - 4x + 8$ are greater than 1, so $x^4 + 64$ is always composite.
 Thus, the smallest such $a$ is $\boxed{8}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: nat and x :: int and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x a. P x a = (is_prime (x^4 + a^2))"
and h1 : "\<not>(\<exists>x. P x a)"
and h2 : "a > 0"
shows  "a = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: If for every integer $x$ and natural number $a$, $P(x, a)$ holds if and only if $x^4 + a^2$ is a prime number. There is no integer $x$ for which $P(x, a)$ holds. If $a$ is a positive natural number, what is $a$? The final answer is 8.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x a :: int and P :: "int => int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x a. P x = x^4 + a^2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. \<not> is_prime (P x)"
shows  "a = 8"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the smallest positive integer $a$ such that $x^4 + a^2$ is not prime for any integer $x.$ The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 For $1 \le a \le 7,$ we give a value of $x$ for which $x^4 + a^2$ is prime: \[ \begin{array}{c|c|c} a & x & a^4 + x^2 \\ \hline 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & 5 \\ 3 & 10 & 10009 \\ 4 & 1 & 17 \\ 5 & 2 & 41 \\ 6 & 1 & 37 \\
 7 & 20 & 160049 \end{array} \]For $a = 8,$ \begin{align} x^4 + a^2 &= x^4 + 64 \\ &= x^4 + 16x^2 + 64 - 16x^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 8)^2 - (4x)^2 \\ &= (x^2 + 4x + 8)(x^2 - 4x + 8). \end{align}For any positive integer, both factors $x^2 + 4x + 8$ and $x^2 - 4x + 8$ are greater than 1, so $x^4 + 64$ is always composite.
 Thus, the smallest such $a$ is $\boxed{8}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x a :: int and P :: "int => int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x a. P x = x^4 + a^2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. \<not> is_prime (P x)"
shows  "a = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

theorem
fixes a x :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. \<not> prime (x powr 4 + a powr 2)"
